item.title: How to calculate Beta of Apple Inc or any stock using Python
item.description:
In this post, I will show you how to calculate the Beta of Apple Inc using Python.

According to CAPM model, the beta of a stock basically measures the systematic risk of the stock. Beta can be estimated by regressing the following formula:

  • is the Return on asset i
  • is the Market Return. Typically, you can the return of index such as S&P500.
  • is some random constant to be estimated
  • is the beta of asset i to be estimated

The beta is calculated will be quite different for different return period and the sampling period chosen. For this example I chose 3 years of monthly return.

Note that, you could choose shorter period for return such as daily return but daily return could be too noisy and the beta might be measuring noise instead of the systematic risk. It really depends on the nature of the asset you are measuring. For fast growing company a shorter period might be preferred sometime.

For this post, I will reuse the code which I shown in my previous post on how to import finance data from yahoo finance and how to compute the monthly return using pct_change.

%matplotlib inline
import pandas_datareader.data as web
import datetime
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

#start = datetime.datetime(2011,1,1)
start = datetime.datetime(2013,9,1)
end=datetime.datetime(2016,9,28)

#load S&P500
snp500 = web.DataReader("^GSPC", "yahoo", start, end)
#load Apple Inc
aapl = web.DataReader("AAPL", "yahoo", start, end)

aapl_mthly = aapl.resample("BMS").apply(lambda x:x[0])
snp500_mthly = snp500.resample("BMS").apply(lambda x:x[0])

aapl_mret = aapl_mthly.pct_change()
snp500_mret = snp500_mthly.pct_change()

aapl_mret = aapl_mret[1:]
snp500_mret = snp500_mret[1:]

plt.figure()
plt.scatter(x=snp500_mret["Adj Close"], y=aapl_mret["Adj Close"])
plt.xlabel("S&P500 Monthly Return")
plt.ylabel("APPLE INC Monthly Return")
plt.show()

Fortunately, it is simple to estimate and in python using the Linear Regression function in Statsmodel package statsmodels.api.OLS

import statsmodels.api as sm

X = sm.add_constant(snp500_mret["Adj Close"])
y = aapl_mret["Adj Close"]

mod = sm.OLS(y, X)
res = mod.fit()
print(res.summary())

plt.figure()
plt.scatter(x=snp500_mret["Adj Close"], y=y)
plt.plot(snp500_mret["Adj Close"], res.fittedvalues, color="r")
plt.xlabel("S&P500 Monthly Return")
plt.ylabel("APPLE INC Monthly Return")
plt.show()

                            OLS Regression Results                            
==============================================================================
Dep. Variable:              Adj Close   R-squared:                       0.492
Model:                            OLS   Adj. R-squared:                  0.477
Method:                 Least Squares   F-statistic:                     32.87
Date:                Wed, 28 Sep 2016   Prob (F-statistic):           1.92e-06
Time:                        00:19:24   Log-Likelihood:                 58.312
No. Observations:                  36   AIC:                            -112.6
Df Residuals:                      34   BIC:                            -109.5
Df Model:                           1                                         
Covariance Type:            nonrobust                                         
==============================================================================
                 coef    std err          t      P>|t|      [95.0% Conf. Int.]
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
const          0.0041      0.008      0.488      0.629        -0.013     0.021
Adj Close      1.3969      0.244      5.733      0.000         0.902     1.892
==============================================================================
Omnibus:                        7.967   Durbin-Watson:                   2.231
Prob(Omnibus):                  0.019   Jarque-Bera (JB):                8.109
Skew:                          -0.648   Prob(JB):                       0.0173
Kurtosis:                       4.930   Cond. No.                         29.7
==============================================================================

Warnings:
[1] Standard Errors assume that the covariance matrix of the errors is correctly specified.

The result of this simple Linear Regression isn’t very good. The line shown in red seem to be affected by outlier. Even though the Probability of Type I Error for Beta is near to 0, the adjusted result is only 0.477. Which mean only 47.7% of the data’s variation is explained by Beta.

In practice, most stock has low adjusted around 0.1 to 0.5. This is because the single index CAPM’s Beta is only measuring systematic risk. To accord for more type of risk (e.g. Size, Liquidity, etc), you could use multi-index model. If you are interested, you might want to check out Arbitrage Pricing Theory for more information.

Here is all the code put together:

%matplotlib inline
import pandas_datareader.data as web
import datetime
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import statsmodels.api as sm

#start = datetime.datetime(2011,1,1)
start = datetime.datetime(2013,9,1)
end=datetime.datetime(2016,9,28)

#load S&P500
snp500 = web.DataReader("^GSPC", "yahoo", start, end)
#load Apple Inc
aapl = web.DataReader("AAPL", "yahoo", start, end)

aapl_mthly = aapl.resample("BMS").apply(lambda x:x[0])
snp500_mthly = snp500.resample("BMS").apply(lambda x:x[0])

aapl_mret = aapl_mthly.pct_change()
snp500_mret = snp500_mthly.pct_change()

aapl_mret = aapl_mret[1:]
snp500_mret = snp500_mret[1:]

X = sm.add_constant(snp500_mret["Adj Close"])
y = aapl_mret["Adj Close"]

mod = sm.OLS(y, X)
res = mod.fit()
print(res.summary())

plt.figure()
plt.scatter(x=snp500_mret["Adj Close"], y=y)
plt.plot(snp500_mret["Adj Close"], res.fittedvalues, color="r")
plt.xlabel("S&P500 Monthly Return")
plt.ylabel("APPLE INC Monthly Return")
plt.show()

item.title: How well Apple Inc Perform over the past 5 years?
item.description:
Are you interested to know how well Apple Inc’s Stock does compare to S&P500? In this tutorial, I will show you how to compare the cummulative monthly return for Apple Inc and S&P500 using Python

The following code will load the required data for Apple Inc and S&P500. If you need explanation for the code, please refer to my previous tutorial on how to use Python to import finance data from Yahoo Finance.

import pandas_datareader.data as web
import datetime

start = datetime.datetime(2011,1,1)
end=datetime.datetime(2016,9,20)

#load S&P500
snp500 = web.DataReader("^GSPC", "yahoo", start, end)
#load Apple Inc
aapl = web.DataReader("AAPL", "yahoo", start, end)

Let’s plot the chart for S&P500 and Apple Inc using matplotlib first.

%matplotlib inline
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.figure()
plt.title("S&P500")
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.plot(snp500["Adj Close"])
plt.xlabel("Date")
plt.ylabel("indices")
plt.show()

plt.figure()
plt.title("AAPL")
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.plot(aapl["Adj Close"])
plt.xlabel("Date")
plt.ylabel("US$")
plt.show()

To get the monthly return, first use pandas resample to resample the daily price to monthly price using the price from first business day of the month. If you are interested in different frequency of price, you can specify the frequency you are interested in the argument of resample. Refer to timeseries offset aliases

B       business day frequency
C       custom business day frequency (experimental)
D       calendar day frequency
W       weekly frequency
M       month end frequency
BM      business month end frequency
CBM     custom business month end frequency
MS      month start frequency
BMS     business month start frequency
CBMS    custom business month start frequency
Q       quarter end frequency
BQ      business quarter endfrequency
QS      quarter start frequency
BQS     business quarter start frequency
A       year end frequency
BA      business year end frequency
AS      year start frequency
BAS     business year start frequency
BH      business hour frequency
H       hourly frequency
T       minutely frequency
S       secondly frequency
L       milliseonds
U       microseconds
N       nanoseconds

aapl_mthly = aapl.resample("BMS").apply(lambda x:x[0])
snp500_mthly = snp500.resample("BMS").apply(lambda x:x[0])

Let’s print the first 5 of aapl_mthly out.

aapl_mthly.head()
Open High Low Close Volume Adj Close
Date
2011-01-03 325.640003 330.260002 324.840012 329.570000 111284600 43.104243
2011-02-01 341.299988 345.649994 340.980007 345.030006 106658300 45.126247
2011-03-01 355.470005 355.719997 347.680000 349.309998 114034200 45.686024
2011-04-01 351.110012 351.589996 343.300007 344.560009 104665400 45.064776
2011-05-02 349.739994 350.469997 345.500004 346.279995 110678400 45.289732

Monthly Return formula: Fortunately, return could be easily calculated using pct_change. I will use the resampled monthly start price to compute the monthly return.

aapl_mret = aapl_mthly.pct_change()
snp500_mret = snp500_mthly.pct_change()

aapl_mret.head()
Open High Low Close Volume Adj Close
Date
2011-01-03 NaN NaN NaN NaN NaN NaN
2011-02-01 0.048090 0.046600 0.049686 0.046910 -0.041572 0.046910
2011-03-01 0.041518 0.029134 0.019649 0.012405 0.069154 0.012405
2011-04-01 -0.012265 -0.011610 -0.012598 -0.013598 -0.082158 -0.013598
2011-05-02 -0.003902 -0.003186 0.006408 0.004992 0.057450 0.004992

Notice that the first row contains NaN values because there is no previous price available to compute the return since it is the first row. I will use slicing to remove the first row.

aapl_mret = aapl_mret[1:]
snp500_mret = snp500_mret[1:]

aapl_mret.head()
Open High Low Close Volume Adj Close
Date
2011-02-01 0.048090 0.046600 0.049686 0.046910 -0.041572 0.046910
2011-03-01 0.041518 0.029134 0.019649 0.012405 0.069154 0.012405
2011-04-01 -0.012265 -0.011610 -0.012598 -0.013598 -0.082158 -0.013598
2011-05-02 -0.003902 -0.003186 0.006408 0.004992 0.057450 0.004992
2011-06-01 -0.002488 0.004737 -0.002460 -0.002224 0.252916 -0.002224

Now, let’s compute the cummulative Return using the following formula:

Pandas comes with cumprod to compute the cummulative return for every rows.

aapl_cumret = (aapl_mret+1).cumprod()
snp500_cumret = (snp500_mret+1).cumprod()

aapl_cumret.head()
Open High Low Close Volume Adj Close
Date
2011-02-01 1.048090 1.046600 1.049686 1.046910 0.958428 1.046910
2011-03-01 1.091604 1.077091 1.070311 1.059896 1.024708 1.059896
2011-04-01 1.078215 1.064585 1.056828 1.045484 0.940520 1.045484
2011-05-02 1.074008 1.061194 1.063601 1.050702 0.994553 1.050702
2011-06-01 1.071336 1.066221 1.060984 1.048366 1.246091 1.048366

I will plot cummulative monthly return for Apple Inc and S&P500 together in the same plot.

plt.figure()
plt.title("Cummulative Monthly Return")
plt.plot(aapl_cumret["Adj Close"], color="r", label="AAPL Cummulative Return")
plt.plot(snp500_cumret["Adj Close"], color="b", label="S&P500 Cummulative Return")
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.legend(loc="upper left")
plt.show()

From this plot, we can actually see that over the past 5 years+, Apple Inc stock actually outperform S&P 500. Good luck to you if you have been holding Apple Inc since 2011!

Here is the code put together…

%matplotlib inline
import pandas_datareader.data as web
import datetime
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

start = datetime.datetime(2011,1,1)
end=datetime.datetime(2016,9,20)

#load S&P500
snp500 = web.DataReader("^GSPC", "yahoo", start, end)
#load Apple Inc
aapl = web.DataReader("AAPL", "yahoo", start, end)

aapl_mthly = aapl.resample("BMS").apply(lambda x:x[0])
snp500_mthly = snp500.resample("BMS").apply(lambda x:x[0])

aapl_mret = aapl_mthly.pct_change()
snp500_mret = snp500_mthly.pct_change()

aapl_mret = aapl_mret[1:]
snp500_mret = snp500_mret[1:]

aapl_cumret = (aapl_mret+1).cumprod()
snp500_cumret = (snp500_mret+1).cumprod()

plt.figure()
plt.title("Cummulative Monthly Return")
plt.plot(aapl_cumret["Adj Close"], color="r", label="AAPL Cummulative Return")
plt.plot(snp500_cumret["Adj Close"], color="b", label="S&P500 Cummulative Return")
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.legend(loc="upper left")
plt.show()

item.title: Using Python Pandas to read stock quote or index from Yahoo finance
item.description:
In this tutorial, you will learn how to use python pandas to read stock quote or index from yahoo finance.

Since pandas 0.17.0, the subpackage pandas.io.data will be removed. This subpackage will be replaced with pandas-datareader. For this tutorial, I will be using pandas-datareader.

Let’s import the Pandas datareader and datetime package. We will be using the datetime function to specify the start and end date.

import pandas_datareader.data as web
import datetime

The arguments for datetime.datetime are: Year, Month and Day. I will specify the start date as 2011/1/1 and end date as 2016/9/22

start = datetime.datetime(2011,1,1)
end=datetime.datetime(2016,9,20)

Now let’s load in the data using DataReader. The argument for DataReader are: Stock Quote, Source (e.g. Yahoo, Google, etc), start date, end date

#load S&P500
snp500 = web.DataReader("^GSPC", "yahoo", start, end)
#load Apple Inc
aapl = web.DataReader("AAPL", "yahoo", start, end)

Let’s examine the data loaded for Apple and S&P500

snp500.head()
Open High Low Close Volume Adj Close
Date
2011-01-03 1257.619995 1276.170044 1257.619995 1271.869995 4286670000 1271.869995
2011-01-04 1272.949951 1274.119995 1262.660034 1270.199951 4796420000 1270.199951
2011-01-05 1268.780029 1277.630005 1265.359985 1276.560059 4764920000 1276.560059
2011-01-06 1276.290039 1278.170044 1270.430054 1273.849976 4844100000 1273.849976
2011-01-07 1274.410034 1276.829956 1261.699951 1271.500000 4963110000 1271.500000 


aapl.head()
Open High Low Close Volume Adj Close
Date
2011-01-03 325.640003 330.260002 324.840012 329.570000 111284600 43.104243
2011-01-04 332.439999 332.500000 328.149994 331.290012 77270200 43.329202
2011-01-05 329.549999 334.339989 329.500011 334.000008 63879900 43.683640
2011-01-06 334.719997 335.249996 332.900009 333.729988 75107200 43.648325
2011-01-07 333.989994 336.349995 331.900013 336.120003 77982800 43.960913


Now, let’s put everything together!

import pandas_datareader.data as web
import datetime

start = datetime.datetime(2011,1,1)
end=datetime.datetime(2016,9,20)

#load S&P500
snp500 = web.DataReader("^GSPC", "yahoo", start, end)
#load Apple Inc
aapl = web.DataReader("AAPL", "yahoo", start, end)
